document_title: New Device for High-Throughput Viability Screening of Flow Biofilms
summary_full: This paper introduces a novel device, the BioFlux system, designed for high-throughput screening of continuous flow biofilms. Traditional methods for assessing biofilm viability are time-consuming and not suitable for high-throughput applications. The BioFlux device utilizes microfluidic channels within a standard well plate format, allowing for controlled fluid flow and compatibility with plate readers. The study demonstrates that using green fluorescent protein (GFP)-expressing bacteria combined with propidium iodide (PI) staining and plate reader fluorescence measurement provides a rapid and accurate method for determining biofilm viability. This method was validated against traditional plate counts and fluorescence microscopy. The system was successfully used to screen the efficacy of several antimicrobials against Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 flow biofilms, highlighting its utility for drug discovery and biofilm research.
key_findings: Developed a BioFlux device enabling high-throughput screening of 96 individual flow biofilms simultaneously.
Established a rapid and accurate method for assessing flow biofilm viability using GFP-expressing bacteria, propidium iodide staining, and plate reader fluorescence.
Validated the GFP-PI fluorescence method against colony counts and fluorescence microscopy, showing strong correlations.
Demonstrated the utility of the BioFlux system for screening the effects of antimicrobials on flow biofilm viability.
Showed that the LIVE/DEAD BacLight stain can overestimate biofilm viability at low antimicrobial concentrations, unlike the GFP-PI method.
future_research_fields: High-throughput screening of other biofilm parameters, such as extracellular matrix formation or protein expression.
Development of alternative viability assays for non-GFP-expressing bacteria in the BioFlux system.
Investigating the use of fluorogenic substrates for metabolic activity-based biofilm screening.
Further exploration of hydrodynamic influences on biofilm resistance and behavior.
conclusions: The BioFlux device, coupled with GFP-PI fluorescence measurement via a plate reader, provides a reliable and efficient method for high-throughput screening of flow biofilm viability. This system overcomes the limitations of traditional methods and is suitable for evaluating the efficacy of antimicrobial agents against flow biofilms.
impact_statement: This work presents a significant advancement in biofilm research by enabling rapid, high-throughput screening of flow biofilms, which are more representative of natural conditions, thus accelerating the discovery of new antibiofilm compounds and strategies.
